Good question. You need to know what will compile or won't compile while you're writing. That's not a big deal - but it starts to get a little rough when you're trying to prototype. Scratch that - i don't think I could actually prototype in Rust. So it helps you get to stable production ready code but I feel like it has to take a long time to do it until you're really seasoned? My problem is I am indecisive and I don't want to worry about safety until I've decided the thing I just wrote is what I want. Usually 2-3 iterations...

messages.text: <@UPUBAM63X> What do you mean by seeing many steps ahead?

elements.text: What do you mean by seeing many steps ahead?

messages.text:
> For what use cases would you choose Go rather than Julia?
As was already mentioned, anything that needs to be deployed to an end user. Even with stuff like PackageCompiler making progress, Go (and essentially anything that supports static compilation) is lightyears ahead.

elements.text: For what use cases would you choose Go rather than Julia?

As was already mentioned, anything that needs to be deployed to an end user. Even with stuff like PackageCompiler making progress, Go (and essentially anything that supports static compilation) is lightyears ahead.

messages.text:
> Syntax is really simple
I always thought so too but recently I found that this seems to depend on your previous experience with programming languages.

The new <http://exercism.io|exercism.io> tooling is being rewritten in Nim rather than Go and part of the reason is that a lot of people said they were unable to read Go syntax well enough to debug the tools as occasional users.

messages.text:
Well I can't give an honest assessment of Rust... I spent 3-4 days trying to make a static graph type and failed. I think the idea is, Rust helps good C programmers write memory safe programs without C? But, I'm not good at C, and found it really challenging to learn. I'm sure Rust will do super duper well - but it's pretty close to brutal for me to learn.

Humans are typically bad at programming for 1 reason. They lack the ability to see 7 steps ahead of complicated interactions. Rust, kind of wants you to be able to see at least 4 steps ahead to even compile. That's a tall ask and makes the shift from scripting languages incredibly jarring. Go is a lot gentler, it's got some twists, but it doesn't demand the developer to have a huge chunk of computer science memorized and fresh for applications. You can get away with a lot less thinking.

messages.text: Did you also look into Rust lately? How does that stack up here?

elements.text: Did you also look into Rust lately? How does that stack up here?

messages.text:
What I like about it over julia so far, is it's strongly typed and statically compiled by design. Packages are actually easier to use once you get your head around the idea that the compiler will figure out how to execute your files (no "include "____.jl"). I like method based interfaces too, pretty neat.

What I don't like compared to julia. No multidispatch - some common design patterns emerge - but not horribly. The math support is weak. It does exist, it's not the worst, but, yea compared to Julia it's like a desert. No worse than say Rust though.

elements.text:
What I like about it over julia so far, is it's strongly typed and statically compiled by design. Packages are actually easier to use once you get your head around the idea that the compiler will figure out how to execute your files (no "include "____.jl"). I like method based interfaces too, pretty neat.

What I don't like compared to julia. No multidispatch - some common design patterns emerge - but not horribly. The math support is weak. It does exist, it's not the worst, but, yea compared to Julia it's like a desert. No worse than say Rust though.

messages.text: performance is usually pretty good. sit's somewhere between Java and C. Syntax is really simple. But it has some downsides. Lack of generics(for a year or so) but there are ways around that by composition and interfaces. It has memory safety among other things, so it's a lot easier and safer than say C or C++. Nice thing is, the linter is really smart, and the compiler will tell you about type issues before you run your code(kinda like Rust, but way less intense)

elements.text: performance is usually pretty good. sit's somewhere between Java and C. Syntax is really simple. But it has some downsides. Lack of generics(for a year or so) but there are ways around that by composition and interfaces. It has memory safety among other things, so it's a lot easier and safer than say C or C++. Nice thing is, the linter is really smart, and the compiler will tell you about type issues before you run your code(kinda like Rust, but way less intense)

messages.text: for building binaries that are statically compiled it's pretty nice. It doesn't make the smallest executables but they are considerably smaller than julia(100x smaller usually)

elements.text: for building binaries that are statically compiled it's pretty nice. It doesn't make the smallest executables but they are considerably smaller than julia(100x smaller usually)

messages.text: Google created Golang for large software projects. It’s supposed to be simple, easy to understand, and just work.

elements.text: Google created Golang for large software projects. It’s supposed to be simple, easy to understand, and just work.

messages.text: <@U01CQTKB86N> has joined the channel

> . Anyone have projects in golang they can talk about? :slightly_smiling_face:
Nothing big but if I need a small cli or web tool for something, I usually write it in Go. Being able to compile everything into a standalone binary is a lot less hassle than deploying Julia or Python
